chiefly at the University of Geneva,
Switzerland, fitted him well for the

Publicity Being Given in Frederick
Paper. Dance to Follow

Six o'clock this evening will
mark the zero hour for the invasion of Frederick. The attacking
force will consist of the Musical
Club, with its best numbers which
are designed to take the town by
storm, and a large number of
camp followers in the form of
Hopkins students. The party will
travel by bus, and will leave the
Barn, so the notice states, at six
o'clock sharp. The offer to take
non-members on the trip for $3.50,
which includes admission to the
concert, is a real inducement, especially in view of the fact that
it has been definitely announced
that Hood College students will
attend in force. This last item
seemed so important to the club
officers that they included it in
their notices announcing the trip.
Arrangements Fully Made

Captain-elect Willson of the
Pennsylvania football team for
1925 returned from the post-season invasion of California with a
broken ankle. Fred Wray, head
line coach, is dickering for terms
with Washington University, he
has had great success at Pennsylvania and will be a hard man to
lose.
Basketball had a setback when
the varsity met Navy, who have
been undefeated so far this season. The crew has been called out
for practice and the coaches have
started to work on wrestling and
track.

All arrangements for the concert have been completed. With
the co-operation of the Frederick
National Guard unit, under whose
auspices the affair is being given,
the Armory has been secured; invitations have been sent to patronesses; and a ticket selling campaign has been carried on. Further interest has been created by
a 'series of four advance articles,
which appeared in the Frederick
Evening News due to the efforts
of Henry Turnbull, publicity
agent for the club.

FOUR NEW MEN ON
HULLABALOO STAFF
Four new men were appointed to the Hullaboloo Business Staff at a meeting held
last Monday in the barn.
George J. Snoops, '26, J. Wilson Hunter, '25, Kenneth H.
Dennis, '26, Karl Miller, '25,
and Chauncey Tatum, '25,
were given the positions by
Philip Sachs, Advertising
Manager, because of the excellence of their work.
George
Hess, Business
Manager, urged further cooperation on the staff and expressed his optimism in view
of the strides already taken toward the production of the
year-book.
A final big drive for ads
will be launched in the near
future.

Six o'clock this evening will
mark the zero hour for the invasion of Frederick. The attacking
force will consist of the Musical
Club, with its best numbers which
are designed to take the town by
storm, and a large number of
camp followers in the form of
Hopkins students. The party will
travel by bus, and will leave the
Barn, so the notice states, at six
o'clock sharp. The offer to take
non-members on the trip for $3.50,
which includes admission to the
concert, is a real inducement, especially in view of the fact that
it has been definitely announced
that Hood College students will
attend in force. This last item
seemed so important to the club
officers that they included it in
their notices announcing the trip.

Captain-elect Willson of the
Pennsylvania football team for
1925 returned from the post-season invasion of California with a
broken ankle. Fred Wray, head
line coach, is dickering for terms
with Washington University, he
has had great success at Pennsylvania and will be a hard man to
lose.

the varsity met Navy, who have
been undefeated so far this season. The crew has been called out
for practice and the coaches have
started to work on wrestling and
track.

All arrangements for the concert have been completed. With
the co-operation of the Frederick
National Guard unit, under whose
auspices the affair is being given,
the Armory has been secured; invitations have been sent to patronesses; and a ticket selling campaign has been carried on. Further interest has been created by
a 'series of four advance articles,
which appeared in the Frederick
Evening News due to the efforts
of Henry Turnbull, publicity
agent for the club.
